captions.text: MIKE MUSTO: OK.

We're in Northern Chicago where
we're supposed to meet

with Dru Diesner and his
wicked '72 Nova.

We told him to meet us here,
but, for the life of me, I
don't know where he is.
So I don't know.
Thad, any ideas?
Tommy, anything?
I don't know.
Oh, wait.
Yeah, Dru's over there.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
MIKE MUSTO: OK.

So we're here with Dru Diesner
in Northern Chicago and his
wicked '72 Nova.

Now, there are certain cars that
I want to film, certain

cars that I want people
to know about.

I first heard about your
car, I guess, about
3 or 4 years ago.

It's a '72 Nova packing
a little extra
punch under the hood.
DRU DIESNER: Little bit.

MIKE MUSTO: And it's the
definition of the sleeper car,

the ultimate definition
of the sleeper car.
Why?
Give me a reason.

Tell everybody why this
thing is so bad ass.
DRU DIESNER: Why not?

Well, the guy that
built the car--
I didn't build the car.

The car was built by a gentleman
named Kurt Urban,

which at that time had a shop
in the Detroit area called
Kurt Urban Performance.
MIKE MUSTO: Right.

DRU DIESNER: Or Wheel to Wheel,
now he's Kurt Urban
Performance.

He actually went through
and did what we
all dream of doing.
MIKE MUSTO: Yeah.

DRU DIESNER: Everybody sits
around with their buddies and

drinks beer and talks about
how they would build the
ultimate sleeper.

This gentleman actually
set about doing it.
MIKE MUSTO: Yeah.
And he actually did in spades.
DRU DIESNER: Yes.

MIKE MUSTO: What do we got
powering this thing?

DRU DIESNER: It's a twin
supercharged LS motor with
water to air inner coolers.

It makes almost 1,200
horsepower.

MIKE MUSTO: For those that don't
know, I mean, when you

go to car shows, I mean
obviously all the paint,
everything is original.
Patina is original.

So what are people's
first reaction?

Do they look at the car
and go, well, why did
you bring this here?

DRU DIESNER: Exactly, especially
at a cruise night.

I'll stand back and watch
people's reactions.
MIKE MUSTO: Right.

DRU DIESNER: They walk up on
it like, why is this guy
wasting this space?
Why is the car here?

But then when they get a little
closer and see the
under hood--
MIKE MUSTO: Right.

DRU DIESNER: --then their
jaws drop a little.

MIKE MUSTO: Right,
right, right.

DRU DIESNER: And as they
continue to go around and look

at the rest of the car,
they start scratching
their head in disbelief.

MIKE MUSTO: So what's it like
owning a car that runs nines

and a quarter, incinerates
tires that
are that big at will?

I mean, because this has
got to be like--
this is a play toy.
This is a toy.
DRU DIESNER: It's a toy.
It's a toy.

But, I drive it back
and forth to work.

I mean, you can do anything
you want with this car.

MIKE MUSTO: So the
next question.
So can we go for a ride?
DRU DIESNER: Oh, absolutely.
MIKE MUSTO: Can I drive it?
DRU DIESNER: Absolutely.
MIKE MUSTO: Let's go.

Have fun and don't
get arrested.

That's the words that Dru
Diesner said to me as I

climbed behind the wheel
of his 1972 Nova.

Now, have fun and don't get
arrested can mean many things.

It could mean don't
get arrested
when you go out drinking.

It could mean don't get arrested
if you're, I don't

know, doing naughty things in
the back seat of a car.

In this case, what it means is
don't get arrested driving my

1200-horsepower Nova on the
back streets of Chicago.

This thing is what you
would call a sleeper.

I would actually call
it a super sleeper.

A 1200-horsepower, LS block,
[INAUDIBLE], twin

supercharged, with the
capacity to basically

incinerate any set of tires
that's put behind it and any

automobile that comes
up next to it.

This car will run 9 second
quarter miles.
It's obscene.
It's not a show car.
It's got some dings.
It's got some patina on it.
And it's un-freaking-real.
[CAR ACCELERATING]

MIKE MUSTO: So what's it like
to drive a 1200-horsepower
twin supercharged Nova?
Pretty freakin' cool.

As far as the steering is
concerned, there's really not
much of it.

I mean, it's manual steering,
and you've got to freakin'

crank it to get this
sucker to turn.

You also got to realize that
under your right foot is a big
red button.

It's the same button that
the guys with the
missile silos have.

You push that button, and you
better be prepared to hold on.

Because I'll be honest with
you, this thing goes.
[CAR ACCELERATING]

MIKE MUSTO: Now, that was like,
I don't know, maybe 8
throttle or whatever it is.

You've also got to realize,
like, the steering.
This is the steering.

Now I don't know if you can
see this, but we're still
going straight.
And I'm doing this.

I don't know if I want to
road race this thing.

I think that's a little out of
the spectrum of, you know,
possibilities.

But on any other day, I mean,
if you were to drive this,

aside from all the noise you
hear, I mean, the steering's

on par with any '72 Nova you're
ever going to drive.

This is something that if you're
a car guy and you for

some reason overlook this car,
or you see this episode and

you're like, ah, I would never
want one of those, let me tell

you something, you're
an idiot.

Because this is the definition
of hot rodding.

This car is the epitome
of a muscle car.

1200-horsepower, straight line,
9 second quarter mile,

and all the F-you it can dish
out at any given moment.
Unbelievable.
Simply unbelievable.

Looking in the trunk, you can
see there are 2 tanks.
One is filled with race fuel.

The other with water for
the intercoolers.

However, bags of ice have been
known to make their way inside
on long trips.

And of course, great care was
taken to make sure the

interior was period correct as
well, by way of a Mexican

throw blanket and genuine
Chicago dirt from the bottom
of Dru's shoes.

You know, you start looking
around, and you see how well
everything is integrated.
The roll cage is fantastic.

I mean, it goes right along the
roof line, the windshield

line, and then down
the [INAUDIBLE].

So anybody who's coming up next
to you can't tell what
this car really, really is.

The other thing is if
you look up here,
this lever right here.

This is a switch for a parachute
just so you know.
This guy is following us.

And he looks to be an official
something or other.

So I want to see if he's
going to pull us over.
He might.

This might be Big Muscle's
first pull over.
I don't know yet.
We'll see.

It's very possible we might be
getting hassled by the man.
That's right, the man.
Uh-oh.
Oh, here we go.
[BLEEP]
MIKE MUSTO: How are you, sir?
MALE SPEAKER: Good.
MIKE MUSTO: Oh.
So you're a fan?
MALE SPEAKER: Oh, yeah.
MIKE MUSTO: Oh, he's a fan!
[BLEEP]
MIKE MUSTO: All right.

So, we kind of got pulled over
in a matter of speaking.

Except the guy got out, security
uniform, I'll arrest

you type hat and the
Glock on his hip.
He got out.

He looked at the car and
started laughing.

He goes, this is that Nova
I seen, that crazy Nova.
So did we get pulled over?
Yes.

But we just got pulled over by
the coolest hot rod security
guard I've ever met.

This car, the great thing about
a Nova is that everybody
knows a Nova.

If you grew up in the '70s
or the '80s I can almost

guarantee either somebody in
your family had a Nova, a

teacher of yours had a Nova,
or maybe you had one.

I mean, this is the ultimate
kind of blue collar car.

Because of that, they sold
millions of these things.

And to this day they're still
all over the place.

Now, this one's not like
a Nova SF 396 or
anything like that.

This is just a plain
Jane Nova.

To have anything that looks like
this, with a motor like

this, that's reliable
is pretty amazing.

I mean, you got to remember this
thing has done the Hot
Rod Power Tour.
It's done Drag Week.

For what this car is and what
it does, it's amazing.
Think about this thing.

You pull up to a line, drag race
against a Bugatti Veyron,
you're winning.

Now, what you can't see also
is it's got a flippin'
parachute back there.
Parachute!
[CAR ACCELERATING]
The power is addicting.

It's like when you start it up,
it's like smoking weed.

And then all of the sudden
you're like, I think I want to
go to something heavier.

This is like marijuana, cocaine,
meth, plus ever

stripper you've ever met
with a cherry on top.
Unbelievable!
Woo-hoo!
[CAR ACCELERATING]

MIKE MUSTO: So we just rolled
into this a little bit.

We didn't even explore the
potential of this thing.

And I'll be honest, I'm not
going to go pluck wild in a

1200-horsepower car
that's not mine.

Dru, on the other hand,
said he has no problem
doing that for us.

In fact, his response when
we said, what can
you do with the car?

He said, I'll do anything
you want.

That's a big statement
for guys like us.

Anything we want is a
lot, a lot of stuff
that we want to do.

So we're going to go pick up
Dru and see how much he

actually scares the crap out
of us in this thing.
[CAR ACCELERATING]

MIKE MUSTO: So Dru, I got to
thank you again for bringing
this car out.

I mean, not too many guys dream
of driving a '72 Nova.

But when I first saw this car
years ago, I knew one day I

would have to find the
guy that owned it.

And just not only talk to
him, but I mean, you
let us drive it.
So thank you so much, dude.

DRU DIESNER: Mission
accomplished.
You're very welcome.

MIKE MUSTO: Oh, dude,
it's been fantastic.
DRU DIESNER: Had a good time.
MIKE MUSTO: Cool.

So guys, awesome Nova,
awesome day.

Stay tuned next week for more
Big Muscle on Drive.
All right.

We're sick and tired
of watching
Dru Diesner do burnouts.

As you can tell by the
excitement on Tommy's face, he

told us that we had to either
put up or shut up.
So this is a Toyota Sienna.
MALE SPEAKER: Sienna.

MIKE MUSTO: --minivan
burn out.
Suck it, Dru.
[TIRES  SQUEALING]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

comments.text:
My first car was a 72 Nova that I pulled out of the bush for free. Loved

comments.author: Greg Wiens

comments.text:
P nandee, 
It was along time ago.  I was a farm boy in Southern Manitoba Canada, I was 
14 years old and I got it for free from a farmer that I helped out and did 
lots of baby sitting for in the winter.  
I pulled it out of the bush, got it running, and they gave her to me.  Over 
the next two years I rebuilt the top end, the carb, did lots of body work 
and redid the interior, most of it in shops class at my local high school 
for credit.  
At sixteen, when I wanted to licence it, all I did was go down to the local 
government insurance place (yes, in "communist" Canada our car insurance is 
run by the government.) They did a run on the serial number, asked me where 
I got the car, they knew the lady personally, and five minutes later the 
car was insured! 
At 21 I sold it to a friend for $400 who wanted it for his wedding, and he 
totally restored it. 

The car handled like a pig, it spun the tires with ease (maybe to much 
ease, but as a 15 year old, oh what fun), but best first car ever!
comments.author: Greg Wiens

comments.text:
+Greg Wiens How did handle the paperwork? Or if there was no stolen report 
for the car, for a long time, than it's yours, or how does it work?

comments.text:
Why is there so many foreign dicks in the comments talking shit about a 
video that if they aren't gonna agree with why fucking watch it? you people 
make no sense. i have no problem with foreign cars and i don't talk shit 
about them but remember that in 1969 when the yank nova came out it was a 
super car and it ran low 12s with slicks on the back straight from the 
factory, same with the copos...novas aren't just old granny cars they were 
quicker than the porches and ferraris back then, yea they can't handle who 
cares if your gonna bitch go bitch on some foreign car videos like honestly 
what is the deal with you coming here and ripping on our videos...and ik 
that all I'm gonna get is more of you assholes trying to prove a point but 
idc all cars are equal, they all have either more power or better 
steering...every car is the fucking same, only difference is what you 
respect...dont be a cock and bash on other people hobbies just go somewhere 
else and talk about foreign cars if you want to and have fun that way just 
stop busting our balls because you think it makes you feel good﻿

I copied and pasted what I typed. You must have typed it because you used

comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+Alan Schulte

Or are you criticising my use of English, when i am the only one here who

You Americans never cease to amaze me with your stupidity!
comments.author: Discofreestyle

comments.text:
+Discofreestyle
And here's what I typed, with CORRECT grammar.

" I think these keyboard warriors from Europe and Asia hate on American 
muscle because they don't know about what it's all about here. They don't 
realize that it's a different style of driving here, that its a way of 
life, that there are memories behinds a specific car.

All those keyboard warriors from Europe and Asia think that's everything is 
about drifting or going around a twisty turny track. Whereas with American 
muscle it's all about the nostalgia, history, memories, and the cars stile. 
These old cars have a style, a spirit that's lost to all modern cars.... 
And they don't understand that. They think that the newer the better, 
instead of realizing that there are cars built in the US that are over 100 
years old! I live in Minnesota, I see plenty of classic American iron 
rolling around... I've never seen one of the first Honda's or Toyota's sold 
here in the US rolling around Minnesota. "
comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+Discofreestyle
You sound like the typical European... arrogant, pompous, and 
egotistical. Also, to borrow something from what you typed in your last 
comment: Please, do yourself a favor and don't make bullshit assumptions 
about the habits of Americans when it comes to ANYTHING American. 

I based my comment off of the fact that I've seen Europeans do nothing but 
hate on American cars saying how much better their brand-new BMW, 
Rolls Royce, Mercedes, Vauxhall, etc. is compared to something built 50 
years ago in the United States.

Now, there is one thing you're right about... I do not have a passport. But 
this is not because I lack the ambition to travel, but because I lack the 
FUNDS to travel. Because while it is fairly inexpensive to travel in 
Europe, that is not so in the United States.  So don't go making 
assumptions.

But once again you're wrong because I do not watch the news. It's nothing 
but trash today. I do not believe that the Earth is 6,000 years old... in 
fact I believe mainstream science's agreement that the earth is closer to 
4,000,000,000 years old. And we are the greatest country in the world, we 
may not be as great as we once were. Now, I'm going to guess by your 
atrocious spelling that you're some kind of Limey prick whose only goal in 
life is to kiss the entire royal family's ass. So don't forget, if AMERICAN 
ships with AMERICAN supplies didn't risk the Wolf Packs of the last 
European war your entire island would have been choked off by the Nazis and 
you'd be living under fascist rule.

So do us a favor (and this is for all Europeans), stop making up bullshit 
on YouTube about what we Americans do and do not think and or do.

Auf Wiedersehen - you Limey douchebag.
comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+Alan Schulte *All those keyboard warriors from Europe and Asia think 
that's everything is about drifting or going around a twisty turny track. 
Whereas with American muscle it's all about the nostalgia, history, 
memories, and the cars stile. These old cars have a style, a spirit that's 
lost to all modern cars.... And they don't understand that. **They think 
that the newer the better**, instead of realizing that there are cars built 
in the US that are over 100 years old!*

Really?! Over 100 whole years old??!! Incredible...

I've been into buildings in the last 24 hours that are twice as old as your 
entire country, and yet you somehow think that we prefer things 'new'. 
Please, do yourself a favour and don't make bullshit assumptions about the 
habits of Europeans when it comes to cars. As with the vast majority of 
your imbecilic countrymen, i very much doubt you even have a passport, let 
alone the ambition to visit the continent you seem to know so much about.

Although i'm sure we won't be missing much.

You stick to thinking you live in the greatest country in the world, 
watching Fox News and believing that the Earth is only 6,000 years old, but 
do us a favour, stop maing up bullshit on YouTube about what we Europeans 
do and don't think.

Cheers.
comments.author: Discofreestyle

comments.text:
+Discofreestyle
How am I trying to lecture you Europeans? None of my comments look or read 
like lectures. Would you care to enlighten me?
comments.author: Alan Schulte

comments.text:
+Alan Schulte An American trying to lecture Europeans about history. Oh the 
irony!
comments.author: Discofreestyle

comments.text:
+gang plank I can picture you, sitting in the corner of your dirty room in 
your mom's basement, masturbating to old episodes of Top Gear. Seriously, 
grow up a little.

I drive a 1971 Buick Riviera Boattail with a 455 V8 and a 4 barrel carb. 
Gigantic, slow, heavy, and you don't steer it so much as you aim it, and I 
love the thing. Driving in it is smooth like a boat on a placid lake. The 
front seat is like a couch. You can almost turn the steering wheel by 
blowing on it. Thing weighs 4300ish pounds. Also, you can break the tires 
loose easy as hell with 300bhp and almost 500ft-lbs of torque. Wouldn't 
trade it for the world. 

The thing about being a real car guy is that you can respect everyone's 
choices no matter what they are. I'm not gonna pull up next to some guy in 
a Prius and smoke him out just because he's driving a Prius. I'm not going 
to go on the internet and put up immature hateful comments about someone's

as much as i can, cause god knows, i wouldnt buy any other car﻿
